evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the early historical timeframe (hist_t1_early).
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists defeaters by accounting for all available evidence and excluding alternative causes in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 early historical context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination during critical phases.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the early historical timeframe (hist_t1_early).

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP despite communication attempts indicates coordination breakdown.
No mechanical faults were reported, so mechanical failure is unlikely.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation without communication issues, or mechanical faults causing the incident, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew, but H4-H5 indicate a failure to stop at the TRP and collision with the blast barrier, supporting a communication/coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the pushback continuation was due to communication failure or procedural deviation.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination during critical phases.

defeaters: If evidence showed that the incident was primarily caused by procedural deviation without communication breakdown
If mechanical or environmental factors were proven to be the main cause

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists defeaters by accounting for all available evidence and excluding alternative causes in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 early historical context.

Marking deficiencies did not contribute significantly as no evidence supports this.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or hardware failures, or if marking deficiencies were documented as causing confusion, the conclusion might change.
If procedural deviations were clearly documented as the primary cause, the explanation would be less resistant to defeaters.
